intro: Macromeria cinerascens, commonly known as the ash-leaf mallow, is a herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy, ovate leaves that turn a grayish-white color as they age. Its flowers are typically pink or red, with five petals and a prominent central stamen. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands and along stream banks.
